item.title: Bosbury Probate Material 1681-1700
item.description: There are surviving probate documents for 37 Bosbury people in the period 1681-1700.
item.dc:creator: SylviaP

item.title: Bosbury Probate Material 1661-1680
item.description: There are surviving probate documents for 49 Bosbury people during the period 1661-1680.
item.dc:creator: SylviaP

item.title: Bosbury Probate Material 1641-1660
item.description: There are surviving probate documents for 14 Bosbury people during the period 1641-1660. The disruption of the Civil War and then the abolition of the church courts during the Interregnum mean that not many probate documents survive from this time.
item.dc:creator: SylviaP

item.title: Bosbury Probate Material 1621-1640
item.description: There are surviving probate documents for 23 Bosbury people in the period 1621-1640.
item.dc:creator: SylviaP

item.title: Bosbury Probate Material before 1540
item.description:
The Statute of Wills (1540) made it legal to devise (leave) certain types of land. After 1540 wills had to be in two forms - the will, dealing with moveable property, and the testament, dealing with real property. This is why most wills use the formula 'last will and testament'.

Unfortunately, there are very few surviving probate documents for Bosbury people before 1540.
item.dc:creator: SylviaP

item.title: Bosbury Probate Material 1601-1620
item.description: From the start of the 17th century, more probate documents survive. There are surviving documents for 37 Bosbury people from 1601-1620. Three of them were proved at the Prerogative Court of Canterbury.
item.dc:creator: SylviaP

item.title: Bosbury Probate material 1581-1600
item.description:
There are 19 surviving probate documents for Bosbury people between 1581 and 1600. Three of these were proved at the Prerogative Court of Canterbury. These were for William Wood and Anthony Washburne, both described as 'gentlemen' and Thomas Lawrence, a fuller, which gives an indication of the importance of the cloth trade at this period.

Transcripts are available below.
item.dc:creator: SylviaP

item.title: Bosbury Probate Material 1561-1580
item.description:
There are 17 surviving sets of probate documents for Bosbury people between 1561 and 1580. Only one of them, Richard Harford, a wealthy landowner, had his will proved at the Prerogative Court of Canterbury, as that of his father John had been in 1559.

 

The transcripts are available below.
item.dc:creator: SylviaP

item.title: Bosbury Probate Material 1541-1560
item.description: There are surviving probate documents for 13 Bosbury people who died in this period. The transcripts are available listed below.
item.dc:creator: SylviaP

item.title: Bosbury Probate Material - an Introduction
item.description:
There are surviving probate documents for 210 Bosbury people who people who died up to and including 1700. These documents are kept at the Herefordshire Record Office and the National Archives at Kew. All the material pre-1700 is being transcribed by VCH volunteers. Some post-1700 wills of significant people, including clergymen, will also be transcribed.

These transcripts have modernised spellings of the body of the text and of place names, where identification is certain.  Names have been standardised,  but the original spellings of surnnames is given as a variant, e.g. Woddyng is given its modern form Wooding.

For ease of searching, the transcripts have been grouped into time periods:

1501-1540 probate material

1541-1560 probate material

1561-1580 probate material

1581-1600 probate material

1601-1620 probate material

1621-1640 probate material

1641-1660 probate material

1661-1680 probate material

1681-1700 probate material

1701 and later probate material
item.dc:creator: SylviaP
